triples.name: Astroturfing
triples.relevance: The paper proposes a machine learning framework specifically designed to detect astroturf campaigns on social media platforms.

triples.name: Machine learning
triples.relevance: Machine learning is the core technical approach used to build the detection framework for identifying astroturf content.

triples.name: Twitter
triples.relevance: Twitter is the microblogging platform where the study evaluates astroturf detection using real-world campaign data.

triples.name: Microblogging
triples.relevance: The paper focuses on detecting astroturf campaigns on microblogging platforms, specifically examining the unique characteristics of this media type.

triples.name: Network topology
triples.relevance: Topological features of information diffusion networks are used as a key component of the detection framework.

triples.name: Information cascade
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes information diffusion and viral spreading patterns, which are fundamental to understanding cascade dynamics in social networks.

triples.name: Diffusion of innovations
triples.relevance: The paper models how astroturf campaigns spread through networks using information diffusion concepts to detect viral spreading patterns.

triples.name: Misinformation
triples.relevance: The paper proposes a framework to detect political misinformation spread through astroturf campaigns on social media.

triples.name: Viral phenomenon
triples.relevance: Detection of viral spreading of political content is a core objective of the proposed framework.

triples.name: 2010 United States elections
triples.relevance: The 2010 U.S. midterm elections dataset is used as the evaluation context to test the astroturf detection framework's effectiveness.
